title: Hack Analysis: Nomad Bridge, August 2022
description: A routine upgrade on the implementation of one of Nomad’s proxy contracts marked a zero hash value as a trusted root, which allowed messages to get automatically proved. The hacker leveraged this vulnerability to spoof the bridge contract and trick it to unlock funds.

title: Hack Analysis: Beanstalk Governance Attack, April 2022
description: Beanstalk was the victim of a whopping $181M hack, which leveraged the lack of execution delay to push through a malicious governance proposal.

title: Moonbeam, Astar, And Acala Library Truncation Bugfix Review — $1m Payout
description: The bug, which was found within Frontier — the Substrate pallet that provides core Ethereum compatibility features within the Polkadot ecosystem–impacted Moonbeam, Astar Network, and Acala. The estimated potential damage from the vulnerability amounted to approximately $200m across the three projects, which was swiftly prevented
labels: Minting new valid but depegged wrapped tokens.

title: Hack Analysis: Omni Protocol, July 2022
description: The underlying vulnerability, reentrancy, was exploited across two different functions of the same smart contract. Notably, these functions were lacking reentrancy locks and did not follow the checks-effects-interactions pattern. By leveraging the re-entrancy vulnerability on two different functions and using two attacker contracts, the hacker was able to borrow against the collateral and make the market forget about it.

title: 88MPH Theft Of Unclaimed MPH Rewards Bugfix Review
description: Allowed users to steal most of the 88MPH tokens generated from yield contract by depositing an asset and withdrawing the vested 88mph tokens immediately.

title: Mt Pelerin Double Transaction Bugfix Review
description: The bug could have allowed users to drain contract funds.

title: Hack Analysis: Saddle Finance, April 2022
description: Price miscalculation when swapping a token for an LP token.

title: Hack Analysis: Cream Finance Oct 2021
description: Analysis of Cream Finance exploit on Oct 2021, resulting in loss of $130m in available liquidity.

title: Aurora Improper Input Sanitization Bugfix Review
description: Improper impot sanitazion that allowed a bad actor to steal funds using a worthless NEP-141.

title: Aurora Withdrawal Logic Error Bugfix Review
description: Unknown, check manually

title: Moonbeam Missing Call Check
description: Missing call check vulnerability that allows direct theft of native assets.

title: Balancer DoS
description: Unknown, check manually

title: Two Novel Crypto Wallet Exploits, Explained
description: Unknown, check manually

title: Synthetix Logic Error Bugfix Review
description: Logic vulnerability in the fee reclamation and rebate features in Synthetix.

title: Port Finance Logic Error Bugfix Review
description: A malicious user could have withdrawn all their obligation collaterals without paying off their full debt.

title: Sense Finance Access Control Issue Bugfix Review
description: Missing access control issue in the onSwap() function of the Sense Balancer pool that could have allowed a malicious actor to update the oracle data of the Space AMM contract

title: Aurora Inflation Spend Bugfix Review: $6m Payout
description: The vulnerability consisted of an infinite spend bug that, if exploited by a malicious user, could have led to a direct loss of 70k ETH and $200m in other assets.

title: Wormhole Uninitialized Proxy Bugfix Review
description: Upgradeable proxy implementation self-destruct bug that helped prevent a potential lockup of user funds

title: Redacted Cartel Custom Approval Logic Bugfix Review
description: The vulnerability would have allowed a malicious attacker to assign a user’s allowance to themselves, enabling the attacker to steal that user’s funds.

title: Optimism Infinite Money Duplication
description: The bug would have allowed an attacker to replicate money continuously on any chain using a vulnerability found in OVM 2.0 (Optimism Virtual Machine)

title: Polygon Consensus Bypass
description: Consensus bypass vulnerability that would have allowed an attacker to decrease the total staking power, allowing a consensus (⅔ threshold) bypass that could potentially have allowed an attacker to drain all the funds from the deposit manager, engage in unlimited withdrawals, DoS, and more.

title: APWine Incorrect Check of Delegations
description: In the PT tokens, one condition wasn’t checked during the burn of those tokens which could lead to the theft of the yield from the protocol after the two periods.

title: Notional Double Counting Free Collateral
description: Free collateral miscalculation and overpricing by a factor of two could allow a bad actor to drain almost all liquidity.

title: Cronos Theft of Transactions Fees
description: The vulnerability that could allow stealing the fees of the current block in Cronos Blockchain

title: Bitswift Unlimited Mint
description: A front-end critical vulnerability that could allow minting an infinite amount of tokens.

title: Polygon Lack of Balance Check
description: The vulnerability consisted of a lack of balance/allowance check in the `transfer()` function of Polygon’s MRC20 contract and would have allowed an attacker to steal all MATIC from the contract.

title: Enzyme Finance Price Oracle Manipulation
description: Vulnerability Type: flash loan/oracle price manipulation.

title: Harvest Finance Uninitialized Proxies
description: The Dedaub team filed a submission via Immunefi for uninitialized implementation contracts for Uniswap V3 vault proxies. The contracts in scope held a total of $6.4M in Uniswap V3 positions at the time of the submission.

title: Polygon Double-Spend
description: The vulnerability allowed an attacker to exit their burn transaction from the bridge multiple times, up to 223 times. There were around ~$850M at risk. Having just $100k to launch the attack with would result in $22.3M in loss!

title: RocketPool and Lido Front-running
description: The vulnerability allowed a malicious node operator included in Lido or RocketPool to steal user deposits frontrunning the deposit.

title: Belt finance logic error
description: A logic error caused one of the contracts to think it had less money than it did, resulting in excess shares being issued for new deposits.

title: OpenZeppelin Bugfix Review
description: Critical reentrancy vulnerability in OpenZeppelin’s TimelockController, where the “executor” was able to hijack the controller and set the delay to 0, remove the existing “proposers”, set themselves as the “proposer” and take over the Timelock and the contracts associated with it.

title: Tidal Finance Logic Error
description: The logic error permitted a malicious user to claim more rewards from staking than they were entitled to.

title: xDai Stake Arbitrary Call Method
description: The bug allowed a potentially malicious hacker to gain access to funds in a contract.

title: Teller uninitialized proxy
description: The beacon proxy was not initialized and could have been initialized by anyone, including a hypothetical malicious attacker.

title: Alchemix access control
description: Any user could have called setWhitelist() to give an attacker the ability to call the harvest function.

title: MCDex Insufficient Validation
description: A critical vulnerability in MCDEX’s broker contract that would have allowed a malicious user to drain that contract of ETH

title: PancakeSwap Logic Error
description: Due to insufficient validation, a malicious user could have claimed the same winning lottery ticket at least 255 times in a single transaction.

title: Cream Finance
description: A malicious user drains Cream’s liquidity mining rewards contract using the front-end and different wallets.

title: Pods Finance
description: This logic error allows for theft of yield or abuse of the rewards system. A bad actor was able to claim rewards owed to other users and drain the entire contract.

title: Mushrooms Finance Logic Error
description: A logic error leading to a flash loan attack vector.

title: SharedStake Insider Exploit
description: This vulnerability allowed the beneficiary of the time-locked funds to transfer out those funds before those funds were scheduled to be released.

title: Zapper Arbitrary Call Data
description: Using the arbitrary call an attacker could call “transferFrom” and since there was no validation of the data provided, the contract will be forced to transfer all the LP tokens from any victim to the attacker.

title: 88mph Function Initialization
description: The `init()` function was missing an onlyOwner modifier and also there was no initializer to prevent a re-initialization. So `init()` function was unprotected and was callable multiple times.

title: PancakeSwap Content Injection
description: Web content injection vulnerability that would have allowed a malicious user to inject any arbitrary text on PancakeSwap’s website.

title: Bitswift Race Condition
description: The race condition vulnerability would have allowed a malicious user to repeatedly claim the same voucher, which entitles a user to some amount of crypto tokens.

title: Charger Particles Griefing
description: The vulnerability was a griefing/denial of service attack against the protocol that would have allowed a malicious user to create a system where bribes had to be paid for a user to buy or sell an NFT.

title: Mushrooms finance Theft of Yield
description: Theft of Yield using an MEV attack with flash bots.

title: Fei Protocol Flashloan Vulnerability
description: Flash loan-driven market manipulation vulnerability permits a threat actor to drain 60.000 ETH from the contract.

title: Sovryn loan vulnerability
description: The critical vulnerability consisted of a failure to validate that the receiver of the proceeds of a collateralized loan was the same entity as the borrower, meaning a malicious user could request a loan based on unused collateral from another user.

title: Fei Protocol Vulnerability
description: Assuming a situation where the FEI price is below the peg, a malicious user could purchase FEI, pushing the price not just back to the 1:1 peg, but above the peg, receiving some amount of FEI as a buy reward in the process. The user could then drip the FEI back into the Uniswap pool via a transfer (not a swap), which bypasses the burn penalty, and finally, convert the FEI to wETH with a swap. As a result, the attacker receives a wETH from the pool without having (net) sold any FEI.

title: PancakeSwap lottery vulnerability
description: A user could see the lottery draw transaction, compute the winning lottery number, buy the right ticket during the draw, and front-run with a high gas fee to win the lottery. PancakeSwap fixed the vulnerability by updating its contract to include protections against buying using the multibuy method during the drawing phase.

title: ArmorFi postmortem
description: A single Dollar worth of coverage could have enabled a malicious attacker to withdraw far more assets than available. Because the exploit allows them to get 10^18 as much as they purchased.
